answers.answer: It is normal to have fluid that maybe blood-tinged from the nose 2-3 weeks after the surgery.  If it becomes thick and/or foul-smelling, there could be a problem.  Sounds like the surgery affected her olfactory bulb (regulates smell and taste) and the pituitary's regulation. Being it has been four months since the surgery, this is not normal.  This could be permanent damage.What does the NS think?I do know this kind of surgery is VERY delicate and given the age of your mother recovery time could be a longer road.

question: A pituatary tumor was removed on January 20th and 5 days later she had diabetes insipidis and was in ICU for several days.  Ever since she has been dizzy, very weak, cold lower legs and it feels like a tight band on her forhead area.  She also has no smell or taste and is still having big globs of rubbery stuff coming out of her nose.  She has had follow up blood work done and everything came back normal.  She is 81 and always in good condition so we are very worried about this.  It has been almost 4 months since the surgery and we need to know if this is normal at her age.  Could her smell and taste be gone forever?
title: pituatary surgery recovery
